newsitem.title: USA: Recent speeches meant to explain policy - Greenspan.
newsitem.headline: Recent speeches meant to explain policy - Greenspan.

text.p: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan on Tuesday defended his recent comments about financial markets, saying they were intended to explain monetary policy moves the Fed might undertake in the future.

"What I was trying to do in December and what I did in my Humphrey-Hawkins testimony before the Senate the other day was to try to lay out all the various factors which we examine for purposes of monetary policy," Greenspan said in testimony to the House Budget Committeee.

Greenspan was referring to a speech in December in which he questioned whether financial markets had become "irrationally exuberant" and also to the first leg of his Humphrey-Hawkins testimony in which he repeated that question.
In the Humphrey-Hawkins testimony, Greenspan elaborated further on that remark by warning that the huge run-up in U.S. stock prices over the past two years might not be sustainable.

In laying out the factors the Fed is looking at, Greenpsan said it would help avoid a situation where people might respond to a potential policy move by asking, "Why are we (the Fed) doing this in this particular way?"
The Fed chief said he was not trying to "jawbone," or sway the financial markets with his comments.
Given the vast size of the markets, no one person could "affect them in a fundamental way," Greenspan said.
